title: Police Tickets | 2 of 2
question_text:
A local police officer gives out between $1$ and $6\text{ tickets a day}$, the probability distribution table of which is shown above, where $X$ is the number of tickets handed out on any given day.
Assume the number of tickets given out these two days is independent.
If the officer works two days in a row, what is the probability that she gives out more than $10\text{ tickets}$ during these two days?

solution:
For the officer to give out more than $10\text{ tickets}$, one of the following situations must occur:

Day $1 = 5\text{ tickets}$
Day $2 = 6\text{ tickets}$
= $0.14 \times 0.03$

Day $1 = 6\text{ tickets}$
Day $2 = 5\text{ tickets}$
= $0.03 \times 0.14$

Day $1 = 6\text{ tickets}$
Day $2 = 6\text{ tickets}$
= $0.03 \times 0.03$

Add these probabilities together:

$(0.14 \cdot 0.03) +( 0.03 \cdot 0.14) + (0.03 \cdot 0.03) = 0.0093$

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.
